pros:
You can make good friendships.
They give you a chance when others don't. 
It's a good starting job.
cons:
Management can be baest with crew that they are friends with and let them get away with things that would busted for. 

You get disciplined (with reason) only if they don't like you.

Some managers work their hard, whilst others don't care and nothing is getting done because if the relationships they have with the higher-ups. 

Store manager doesn't care and plays on his phone in the office but lectures the management team about they have to "take one in the chin" or "put on a brave face " etc.

The phrase 'customer is always right" applies. Some customers shout at you and treat you so badly and you are told to grow thick skin. As a manager you're the one taking all the heat. Your mental health is gonna be affected if you are a human being who has feelings. On top of that, if a customer phones to complain to the head office, they get vouchers. Not sure if the people there actually give a flying you know what from their tower about the ones that actually work in restaurants. They give vouchers left and right rewarding cutomers for their abusive behaviour. 
The list can go on for ages...

review_title: I would've given them a 1/5 stars
job_title: Crew Member in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I have absolutely no pros to give.
cons: I'm going to do everyone a favor and actually tell the truth on this website. Management at McDonald's is the worst and they do not care about their employees and have pretty much openly said it to our faces. Managers cuss out employees that are under them. We're treated like crap and the "customer is always right" demographic is insanely cherished to the point where even blatant lies and dumb comments are used as an excuse to write us up. We're not treated like people, our comments are disregarded, and we're not given any time to breathe. Ex: I missed my sister's wedding because they said it wasn't a "good enough excuse to not go to work and it would be a write-up if I didn't show". Another example: I am 17 and have to go to high school at 7 in the morning and my managers know this. However, they continue to schedule me til close at midnight. This becomes a problem when other people that are closing do not do their jobs right and I have to do it all myself and am out til 2 in the morning and have to get up to go to school in 5 hours. I have now gone a whole month without working because they refuse to put me on the schedule and I have not gotten paid a dime. My girlfriend is having to pay for MY gas and food because I cannot pay for it myself. It's sad and McDonald's can definitely do better.

review_title: Overall a great place for a first part time job, just watch out for the management.
pros:
You learn a lot transferable skills like:
. Customer Service
. Upselling
. Cash Handling/Operating a Register
. Time Management/Working within Deadlines
. Team Management/Working with a team
. How to work under pressure
. Stock Rotation/Stock Handling
. Conflict Resolution
cons:
. Management can be very toxic at times
. Work Hours can vary a lot and at times managers may coerce you to working hours that aren't possible for you especially if you're studying or have a second job
. Promotion is mostly given to employees who the management likes the most it doesn't really matter if your the hardest worker in the store, if the management aren't fond of you don't expect to be promoted
. Managers tend to have big egos and getting on the bad side of that ego means they can make your work life a living hell if they want to with little to no repercussion 

. I noticed managers tried to knowingly create toxic rivalries/rifts between crew members that were friends/got along well with each other, with the "promise" of advancement/promotion or if they didn't fall for that they were told they weren't working hard enough and were coerced with reduced hours/put on the overnight shifts or whatever was most inconvenient for those crew members etc. . 

I saw this break apart a lot of the team building/camaraderie/friendliness among the crew members as a lot of crew started to become a lot more cut-throat and toxic to each other.
I found that rather disgusting and wanted no part of it.

review_title: Good first experience into working but very network-of-friends driven workplace.
pros:
Training and being trained are good experiences as you cooperate and establish the hierarchal system at Mcdonald's immediately.

Easy utilisation of penalties/bonuses if you're willing to do night shifts.

Teamwork is necessary and you do feel a sense of individual achievement as you do certain tasks for the store for the aim of serving fast food.

Not the most flexible for studying, with the requirement to block days out two weeks in advance and a whole debacle with removing a shift but usually good hours and easy to set changing availabilities each semester or term.

opportunity to fill in shifts on Facebook allows more chance to work and builds reliability that you want to work more.
cons:
Depending on the store's culture, racism or casual insults can be normalised.

Getting shifts can be tough if you aren't a well-liked or friendly with the managers, as new employees are hired every year. This gets increasingly harder as you age.

the older stores are not super appealing to work in, but can easily be fixed if you take it upon yourself to do the cleaning.

review_title: Avoid unless you like doing 3 people's jobs for one person's pay.
pros: Lots of hours, you will get your 40.
